tip: Walking mindfully is something you can practise as you go about your normal day. It’s good to try walking slowly at first, but once you’re used to it, you can practise it at any pace. tip:
Does your brain feel like it's going into meltdown? Try this easy to remember excercise using the acronym S T O P.
S - Stop what you are doing, take three deep breaths in and out.
T - Tune in to your breathing and imagine breathing out any physical or emotional tension as you continue breathing deeply in and out.
O - Observe your surroundings and situation. Focus on identifying anything that you are grateful for.
P - Positive emotions flow from this place of gratitude, use them to guide your actions.

tip: Crowding out is an alternative strategy to change your habits. Instead of trying to stop doing something you can try introducing new and more positive habits so that there is literally no space for the old bad habit. For example you could try drinking water instead of fizzy soft drinks, or swapping a biscuit for a piece of fruit, or go for a walk instead of going on social media.

tip: Sign up for a creative workshop. tip: Don't look at your phone first thing in the morning. When you begin to wake up your brainwaves move through different modes, from the delta waves experienced in deep sleep, to theta waves, which are a daydream state and then into alpha waves when you are awake but not alert. Our bodies need time to adjust and looking at your phone rushes through these modes straight to your beta mode of operation.

tip: Uncompleted tasks stay in our minds more vividly than completed tasks. This phenomenon is known as The Zeigarnik effect, after research by psychologist Bluma Zeignarik.  She gave each subject a puzzle to complete and then interrupted half of the group during the task, but allowed the other half to finish the puzzle. Only 12% of the subjects who completed the task could remember it in detail, while 80% of interrupted subjects remembered what they were doing in detail.
